name: Tartrazine
simple_user_message: May affect activity and attention in some children; EU requires a warning label on products containing this dye.

name: Quinoline Yellow
simple_user_message: Synthetic yellow colour; assessed as safe within ADI but often grouped with other azo dyes due to hyperactivity concerns.

name: Sunset Yellow FCF
simple_user_message: Synthetic orange colour; in mixtures with other colours/preservatives has been linked to small increases in hyperactive behaviour in children.

name: Azorubine / Carmoisine
simple_user_message: Synthetic red colour; EU requires warning about possible effects on activity and attention in children.

name: Ponceau 4R
simple_user_message: Synthetic red colour; warning label required in the EU for possible effects on children’s behaviour.

name: Allura Red AC
simple_user_message: Synthetic red colour; behavioural effects in children considered possible when consumed in mixes with other additives.

name: Benzoic acid and benzoates
simple_user_message: Preservatives used in acidic foods and drinks; generally safe within ADI, but can form benzene when combined with vitamin C in some beverages.

name: Sodium benzoate
simple_user_message: Common preservative in soft drinks; safe within ADI, but with ascorbic acid in acidic drinks can lead to small benzene formation.

name: Nitrites (potassium/sodium)
simple_user_message: Used to cure processed meats; in processed red meat can form carcinogenic nitrosamines, linked to increased colorectal cancer risk.

name: Nitrates (sodium/potassium)
simple_user_message: Converted partly to nitrite in the body; main concern is when used in processed meats due to nitrosamine formation.

name: Sulphur dioxide and sulphites
simple_user_message: Can trigger asthma symptoms and allergic-type reactions in sensitive individuals; must be labelled when above 10 mg/kg or L.

name: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
simple_user_message: Vitamin C used as antioxidant; generally regarded as safe. May react with benzoates in acidic drinks to form traces of benzene.

name: Citric acid
simple_user_message: Common natural acid (found in citrus fruit); JECFA assigned ADI 'not specified' (low toxicity).

name: Polysorbate 80
simple_user_message: Emulsifier used in ice creams and processed foods; ADI 0–25 mg/kg bw/day. Animal data suggest possible gut microbiome effects at high doses.

name: Carboxymethylcellulose
simple_user_message: Thickener/emulsifier; experimental studies suggest high intake may disturb gut barrier and microbiome, especially in a high-fat diet context.

name: Aspartame
simple_user_message: High-intensity sweetener; safe within ADI for general population, but people with phenylketonuria (PKU) must avoid it.

name: Acesulfame K
simple_user_message: Non-sugar sweetener often used in blends (for example, with aspartame); overall intake should stay within ADI; mixes are being studied for metabolic effects.

name: Sucralose
simple_user_message: High-intensity sweetener; considered safe within ADI, but some studies investigate potential gut microbiome and metabolic effects at high intakes.

name: Phosphoric acid
simple_user_message: Acidifier used in colas and processed foods; contributes to total phosphate load, which in high amounts is linked to cardiovascular and kidney stress.
